verses.text: Six days before the Passover, Jesus came to Bethany, where Lazarus was, whom Jesus had raised from the dead.
verses.comment: Bethany, near Jerusalem, is the setting for many key events in Jesus’ final week. The mention of Lazarus connects to John's prior sign showing Jesus' authority over death.

verses.text: So they gave a dinner for Him there. Martha served, and Lazarus was one of those reclining at the table with Him.
verses.comment: Martha’s role as servant echoes her actions in Luke 10:40. The banquet prefigures themes of fellowship and the importance of hospitality with Christ.

verses.text: Mary therefore took a pound of very expensive perfume made of pure nard and anointed Jesus' feet and wiped His feet with her hair. The house was filled with the fragrance of the perfume.
verses.comment: The anointing signifies Jesus as the Messiah (anointed one). Wiping His feet with her hair shows humility and devotion. The act also points forward to His burial.

verses.text: But Judas Iscariot, one of His disciples, who was about to betray Him, said,
verses.comment: Here, John emphasizes Judas’s role as betrayer, beginning to contrast his heart with the devotion shown by Mary.

verses.text: "Why was this perfume not sold for three hundred denarii and given to the poor?"
verses.comment: Three hundred denarii was about a year's wages. The concern for the poor, though outwardly virtuous, is not sincere from Judas.

verses.text: He said this, not because he cared for the poor, but because he was a thief, and having charge of the moneybag, he used to take what was put into it.
verses.comment: John reveals Judas' hypocrisy. This detail underscores the danger of hidden motives, and the importance of discerning true charity.

verses.text: Jesus said, "Leave her alone, so that she may keep it for the day of my burial.
verses.comment: Jesus links Mary’s act to His impending death. The preparation for burial foreshadows the Passion.

verses.text: For you always have the poor with you, but you do not always have me."
verses.comment: Old Testament echoes (Deut. 15:11) remind us to care for the poor, but Jesus hints at His unique presence and the coming sacrifice.

verses.text: When the large crowd of Jews learned that Jesus was there, they came not only because of Jesus, but also to see Lazarus, whom He had raised from the dead.
verses.comment: Lazarus’s resurrection had become a powerful sign, drawing many to faith, prefiguring the resurrection of Christ as a cause for belief.

verses.text: But the chief priests made plans to kill Lazarus also,
verses.comment: Opposition to Jesus intensifies, as even those whom Jesus raised are targeted. This illustrates resistance to grace and truth.

verses.text: because on account of him many of the Jews were going away and believing in Jesus.
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus is spreading through the miracles, threatening the religious establishment.

verses.text: The next day the large crowd that had come to the feast heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The feast refers to Passover, the context for Jesus’ role as the Lamb of God (cf. John 1:29).

verses.text: So they took branches of palm trees and went out to meet Him, shouting, "Hosanna! Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord, even the King of Israel!"
verses.comment: The crowd quotes Psalm 118, recognizing Jesus as King and Messiah. Palm branches symbolize victory and kingship.

verses.text: And Jesus found a young donkey and sat on it, just as it is written:
verses.comment: Riding a donkey fulfills prophecy about the humble Messiah-King.

verses.text: "Fear not, daughter of Zion; behold, your King is coming, sitting on a donkey’s colt!"
verses.comment: Direct quotation from Zechariah, emphasizing Jesus’ fulfillment of messianic prophecy.

verses.text: His disciples did not understand these things at first, but when Jesus was glorified, then they remembered that these things had been written about Him and had been done to Him.
verses.comment: Only after the Resurrection and the coming of the Spirit do the disciples comprehend the significance of Jesus' actions, paralleling Old Testament prophecies.

verses.text: The crowd that had been with Him when He called Lazarus out of the tomb and raised him from the dead continued to bear witness.
verses.comment: Witnessing to miracles is central to evangelization. Public testimony strengthens faith in the truth of Christ.

verses.text: Because of this, the crowd went to meet Him, for they had heard He had done this sign.
verses.comment: ‘Sign’ in John’s gospel refers to miracles revealing Jesus’ divine identity and mission.

verses.text: So the Pharisees said to one another, "You see that you are gaining nothing. Look, the world has gone after Him."
verses.comment: The universality of Jesus' appeal suggests the scope of His mission is global, fulfilling the promises to Abraham.

verses.text: Now among those who went up to worship at the feast were some Greeks.
verses.comment: The Greeks represent the nations—indicating that Christ’s work is for Jew and Gentile alike.

verses.text: So these came to Philip, who was from Bethsaida in Galilee, and asked him, "Sir, we wish to see Jesus."
verses.comment: ‘Seeing Jesus’ here points both to physical and spiritual vision—the desire to encounter the truth.

verses.text: Philip went and told Andrew; Andrew and Philip went and told Jesus.
verses.comment: The disciples mediate access to Jesus, a theme with implications for apostolic ministry and intercession.

verses.text: And Jesus answered them, "The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified.
verses.comment: ‘Son of Man’ (cf. Daniel 7) is a divine title; the ‘hour’ is the Passion, when Jesus’ glory is revealed through suffering and resurrection.

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, unless a grain of wheat falls into the earth and dies, it remains alone; but if it dies, it bears much fruit.
verses.comment: A metaphor for Jesus’ impending death and resurrection. His death will bring forth a spiritual harvest.

verses.text: Whoever loves his life loses it, and whoever hates his life in this world will keep it for eternal life.
verses.comment: Self-denial is necessary for discipleship. Eternal life is offered through a willingness to follow Christ, even at cost.

verses.text: If anyone serves me, he must follow me; and where I am, there will my servant be also. If anyone serves me, the Father will honor him.
verses.comment: Union with Christ is required for service, and promises final glorification. The call to follow Christ includes fidelity and perseverance.

verses.text: "Now my soul is troubled. And what shall I say? 'Father, save me from this hour'? But for this purpose I have come to this hour.
verses.comment: Jesus’ troubled soul reveals His true humanity, yet He is obedient to His salvific purpose.

verses.text: "Father, glorify your name." Then a voice came from heaven: "I have glorified it, and I will glorify it again."
verses.comment: The voice from heaven, as at Jesus’ baptism and transfiguration, affirms His divine sonship and the Father’s active participation in His mission.

verses.text: The crowd that stood there and heard it said that it had thundered. Others said, "An angel has spoken to Him."
verses.comment: Not everyone perceives the Father’s voice, pointing to the mystery of faith and revelation.

verses.text: Jesus answered, "This voice has come for your sake, not mine.
verses.comment: Signs and revelations are provided to strengthen the faith of the hearers.

verses.text: Now is the judgment of this world; now will the ruler of this world be cast out.
verses.comment: Jesus proclaims His victory over the evil one, fulfilling Genesis 3:15. The cross is both judgment and triumph.

verses.text: And I, when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all people to myself."
verses.comment: ‘Lifted up’ refers to crucifixion (see John 3:14). Jesus’ death is the means of universal salvation, drawing all to Him.

verses.text: He said this to show by what kind of death He was going to die.
verses.comment: John clarifies that ‘lifting up’ means crucifixion, fulfilling the prophecies of the suffering servant.

verses.text: So the crowd answered Him, "We have heard from the Law that the Christ remains forever. How can you say that the Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?"
verses.comment: The crowd expected an eternal, victorious Messiah, not a suffering one. The ‘Son of Man’ with everlasting dominion (Daniel 7:14) is unexpectedly connected with suffering.

verses.text: So Jesus said to them, "The light is among you for a little while longer. Walk while you have the light, lest darkness overtake you. The one who walks in darkness does not know where he is going.
verses.comment: Light symbolizes divine revelation and presence. Jesus exhorts them to believe while He is present.

verses.text: While you have the light, believe in the light, that you may become sons of light." When Jesus had said these things, He departed and hid Himself from them.
verses.comment: Becoming ‘sons of light’ speaks of spiritual transformation and belonging to God’s family through faith.

verses.text: Though He had done so many signs before them, they still did not believe in Him,
verses.comment: Despite miracles, rejection of Jesus fulfills the pattern of unbelief prophesied in the Old Testament.

verses.text: so that the word spoken by the prophet Isaiah might be fulfilled: "Lord, who has believed our message, and to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?"
verses.comment: Quoting Isaiah 53:1, John connects Jesus’ rejection to the prophecy of the suffering servant.

verses.text: For this reason they could not believe, for again Isaiah said,
verses.comment: Hardening of hearts is a response to persistent unbelief, referencing Isaiah’s call.

verses.text: "He has blinded their eyes and hardened their hearts, lest they see with their eyes and understand with their heart, and turn, and I would heal them."
verses.comment: This mysterious hardening points to God’s sovereignty and the seriousness of rejecting revelation.

verses.text: Isaiah said these things because he saw His glory and spoke of Him.
verses.comment: Remarkably, John states that Isaiah saw Jesus’ glory (comparing Isaiah 6), suggesting Jesus’ pre-existence and divinity.

verses.text: Nevertheless, many even of the authorities believed in Him, but for fear of the Pharisees they did not confess it openly, lest they be put out of the synagogue;
verses.comment: Fear of man prevents public confession of faith, showing the cost and challenge of discipleship.

verses.text: for they loved the glory that comes from man more than the glory that comes from God.
verses.comment: True discipleship requires seeking God’s approval over human praise. This theme foreshadows the virtue of confessing faith, even under pressure.

verses.text: And Jesus cried out and said, "Whoever believes in me, believes not in me but in him who sent me.
verses.comment: To believe in Christ is to believe in the Father, highlighting the unity and divine mission of Son and Father.

verses.text: And whoever sees me sees him who sent me.
verses.comment: Jesus claims to be the visible revelation of the Father—an explicit statement of His divinity.

verses.text: I have come into the world as light, so that whoever believes in me may not remain in darkness.
verses.comment: Jesus reaffirms His role as the light of the world, bringing salvation and revelation.

verses.text: If anyone hears my words and does not keep them, I do not judge him; for I did not come to judge the world but to save the world.
verses.comment: Jesus’ mission is first redemptive, not condemning. Judgment comes to those who reject the offer of salvation.

verses.text: The one who rejects me and does not receive my words has a judge; the word that I have spoken will judge him on the last day.
verses.comment: The words of Christ are the standard for final judgment—there is a necessity for accepting revelation.

verses.text: For I have not spoken on my own authority, but the Father who sent me has Himself given me a commandment—what to say and what to speak.
verses.comment: Jesus’ teaching has divine authority. The office of teaching continues through those sent by Him with His word and authority.

verses.text: And I know that His commandment is eternal life. What I say, therefore, I say as the Father has told me."
verses.comment: Obeying the word of Christ brings eternal life. The heart of Jesus’ mission is to reveal the Father’s will and give life through fidelity to His word.
